title: No farm, no hindrance to dog triallists
text:
No farm, no hindrance to dog triallists MIKE WATSON Last updated 14:57, February 7 2017 DEREK FLYNN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Dog trialist Freddie Gane, far right, with Marlborough Collie Dog Trial Club members, from left, Trevor Gibson, Scott Downing and Jim Burrows. 
Former musterer, and dog trialist newbie Freddie Gane thought his days of working with dogs were over when he came back to work on the family vineyard in Marlborough. 
He had grown up with dogs on the family's sheep and cropping farm, before a stint mustering in Canterbury's Rakaia Gorge after university. 
"I got hooked working with dogs at that stage but when I came back to work in the vineyard I decided to sell all my dogs." DEREK FLYNN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Huntaways and heading dogs rest up before they go through their paces. 
It didn't take him long to realise his mistake, he said. 
READ MORE: * Keen competition at Marlborough dog trials 
"I got withdrawal symptoms pretty quick, and went out and bought another dog a few months later." 
Soon he had six dogs and a new-found interest in dog trialling with the Marlborough Collie Dog Trial Club. 
Dog trialling was intensive, not to mention a steep learning curve, aided by some light-hearted ribbing from club members, he said. 
"There's a lot of pressure on but I like to call it positive pressure. 
"You are out there with your dogs in front of your mates and you want to do well." Ad Feedback 
With the dog trial season in full swing, Gane said he would often spend morning and night getting his dogs up to scratch for the following weekend's event. 
Gane and other members of the club would be out in force competing at the Flaxbourne trials in Ward on Friday and Saturday. 
The trial was the first in the Nelson/Marlborough region for the season, with competitors collecting points from the four events on the day for qualification towards the national championships. 
Gane and fellow club member Trevor Gibson, an engineer with 15 years' dog trialling experience, don't have the advantage of working their dogs with stock everyday as do many of their farmer peers. 
"It's good to keep on top of your dogs if you don't live on a farm," Gane said. 
"They're all different and they have to be 'reset' from working with stock on the farm to trialling." 
​Club member Scott Downing encouraged more non-farmers to join the club. 
"We're trying to attract more people, like Freddie and Trevor, to dog trialling," Downing said. 
"If they are competitively minded and have passion for dog trials, it's a great way to spend an afternoon." 
The club ran regular training days in an area of Blenheim's Wither Hills Farm Park, which was off limits to the public, for people who wanted to know more about dog trialling and how to train dogs, he said. 
The Flaxbourne dog trials would be held at Kevin Loe's​ property, The Homestead, on Ward Beach Rd, starting Friday morning with the heading events, followed in the afternoon by a zig-zag hunt, and a straight hunt. 
Spectators welcome.
